description.narrative: Since 2009, Zimbabwe#s economy started to recover from the 1999-2008 crises that saw economic output cumulatively declining by more than 45%. Supported by a strong recovery of domestic demand and government consumption, real gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 20.1% in 2009-2011. GDP growth was led by strong growth in mining (107%), agriculture (35%) and services (51%) while recovery in manufacturing sector (22%) has been less vigorous. In order to capitalise on the gains being made, the Government has developed an enabling policy framework with a vision of sustained socio-economic growth and development. The new pro-poor oriented socio-economic development framework, #the Zimbabwe agenda for sustainable socio-economic transformation (ZIM-ASSET)#, has four strategic priorities, (i) value addition and beneficiation; (ii) infrastructure and utilities; (iii) social services and poverty eradication; and (iv) food security and nutrition. In order to move the ZIM-ASSET process forward, the Government of Zimbabwe has recently expressed interest in partnering with UNIDO. In particular and following a meeting between the Director General and the Deputy Minister of Industry and Commerce held in the margins of GC 15, a letter dated 27 February 2014 (received in April 2014) was submitted to UNIDO requesting assistance #
